pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing suspension
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:0.4: 6. The training rule on building huts
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.2: At that time the monks of Āḷavī were building huts by means of begging. The huts were intended for themselves, did not have a sponsoring owner, and were inappropriate in size.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.4: and so the monks kept on asking and begging,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.5: “Give a man, give a servant, give an ox, give a cart, give a machete, give a hatchet, give an ax, give a spade, give a chisel, give a creeper, give bamboo, give reed, give grass, give clay.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.6: People felt oppressed by all the asking and begging, so much so that when they saw a monk they became alarmed and fearful, and they ran away, took a different path, turned away, and closed their doors.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.7: They even ran away when they saw cows, thinking they were monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.8: Just then Venerable Mahākassapa, after completing the rainy-season residence at Rājagaha, set out for Āḷavī.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.9: When he eventually arrived in Āḷavī,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.10: he stayed at the Aggāḷava Shrine.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.11: In the morning Venerable Mahākassapa robed up, took his bowl and robe, and entered Āḷavī for alms.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.12: When people saw him they became fearful and alarmed, and they ran away, took a different path, turned away, and closed their doors.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.13: After finishing his almsround and eating his meal, Venerable Mahākassapa returned and said to the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.14: “Āḷavī used to have plenty of food, and it wasn’t difficult to get by on almsfood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.15: But now Āḷavī is short of almsfood, and it’s not easy to get by on alms.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.17: The monks told Venerable Mahākassapa what had happened.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.1: Soon afterwards, after staying at Rājagaha for as long as he liked, the Buddha too set out wandering toward Āḷavī.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.2: When he eventually arrived at Āḷavī,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.3: he too stayed at the Aggāḷava Shrine.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.4: Venerable Mahākassapa approached the Buddha, bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.5: and told the Buddha what had happened.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.6: The Buddha then had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks of Āḷavī:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.7: “Is it true, monks, that you’re building huts through begging, huts intended for yourself, without a sponsoring owner, and inappropriate in size?
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.8: And that because they were never completed,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.9: you kept on asking and begging
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.11: and people felt oppressed to the point where they now avoid monks?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.14: “… Foolish men, how can you act like this?
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.18: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.19: After rebuking them, he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.1: “Once upon a time, monks, two sages who were brothers lived near the river Ganges.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.2: On one occasion the dragon king Maṇikaṇṭha emerged from the Ganges and approached the younger sage. He encircled him with seven coils and spread his large hood over his head.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.3: Because of his fear of that dragon, the younger sage became thin, haggard, and pale, his veins protruding all over his limbs.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.4: The older sage saw him like this
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.5: and asked him what was the matter.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.7: And the younger sage told him.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.9: The elder sage said, ‘Would you like that dragon not to return?’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.11: ‘Well then, did you see anything belonging to that dragon?’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.12: ‘I saw an ornamental gem on his neck.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.13: ‘In that case ask the dragon for that gem.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.16: Soon the dragon king again emerged from the Ganges and approached the younger sage.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.17: And the sage said to him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.21: ‘The monk is asking for the gem,’ and he quickly left.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.22: Once more the dragon king emerged from the Ganges and approached the younger sage.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.29: Yet again the dragon king emerged from the Ganges.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.30: The younger sage saw him emerging
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.34: The dragon king then spoke these verses to the sage:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.35: ‘My food and drink are abundant and sublime,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.36: And they appear because of this gem.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.37: I won’t give it to you—you ask too much,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.38: Nor will I return to your hermitage.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.39: Like a youth holding a clean stone,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.40: You frighten me, asking for this gem.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.41: I won’t give it to you—you ask too much,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.42: Nor will I return to your hermitage.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.43: And the dragon king Maṇikaṇṭha thought,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.44: ‘The monk is asking for the gem; he wants the gem,’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.45: and he left and never returned.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.46: Because he did not get to see that beautiful dragon, the young sage became even thinner, more haggard and pale, his veins protruding even more.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.47: The older sage saw him like this
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.48: and asked what was the matter.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.50: He replied, ‘It’s because I no longer get to see that beautiful dragon.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.51: The older sage then spoke to him in verse:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.52: ‘One shouldn’t beg from those one wishes to be dear to;
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.53: One is detested for asking for too much.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.54: When the brahmin asked the dragon for his gem,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.55: It left and was never to be seen again.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.56: One will be disliked even by animals, monks, for asking and begging,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.1: “At one time, monks, a certain monk lived in a forest grove on the slopes of the Himalayas.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.2: Not far from that grove was a large, low-lying marsh.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.3: A great flock of birds fed in the marsh during the day and entered the grove to roost at night.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.4: The monk was disturbed by the noise of the flocking birds, and so he came to see me. He bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.6: “I hope you’re keeping well, monk, I hope you’re comfortable;
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.7: I hope you’re not tired from traveling.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.8: And where have you come from?’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.10: And I’m not tired from traveling.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.11: On the slopes of the Himalayas there’s a great forest grove
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.12: and close by a large low-lying marsh.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.13: A large flock of birds feeds in that low-lying marsh during the day and comes at night to roost in that forest grove.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.14: That’s where I’ve come from, Sir,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.15: and I left because I was disturbed by the noise of that flock of birds.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.16: ‘Would you like that flock of birds not to return?’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.18: ‘Well then, go back to that forest grove. In the first part of the night, call out three times,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.20: From whoever roosts in this forest grove, I want a feather.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.21: Each one of you must give me a feather.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.23: and third part of the night do the same thing.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.27: The monk returned to that forest grove and did as instructed.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.37: ‘The monk is asking for a feather; he wants a feather,’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.40: One will be disliked even by animals, monks, for asking and begging,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.5.1: “The father of Raṭṭhapāla, monks, once spoke to his son with this verse:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.5.3: Who come to me and beg—
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.5.5: So why don’t you beg from me?’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.5.7: Nor is one who doesn’t give when asked.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.5.8: That’s why I do not beg from you;
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.5.9: Please don’t hate me for this.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.5.10: If Raṭṭhapāla, who came from a good family, could speak like this to his own father,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.5.11: how much more, then, can people do so to each other.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.1: It’s hard, monks, for householders to acquire and protect their possessions.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.2: And still, foolish men, you kept on asking and begging
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.4: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.5: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.6.1: ‘When a monk, by means of begging, builds a hut without a sponsoring owner and intended for himself, it is to be no more than twelve standard handspans long and seven wide inside.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.7: He must get monks to approve a site where no harm will be done and which has a space on all sides.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.8: If a monk, by means of begging, builds a hut on a site where harm will be done and which lacks a space on all sides, or he does not get monks to approve the site, or he exceeds the right size, he commits an offense entailing suspension.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.1.2: having himself begged for a man, a servant, an ox, a cart, a machete, a hatchet, an ax, a spade, a chisel, a creeper, bamboo, reed, grass, clay.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.1.4: plastered inside or plastered outside or plastered both inside and outside.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.1.6: building it himself or having someone else build it.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.1.8: there is no other owner, either a woman or a man, either a lay person or one gone forth.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.1.12: It is to be no more than twelve standard handspans long:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.1: He must get monks to approve a site:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.2: The monk who wishes to build a hut should clear a site. He should then approach the Sangha, put his upper robe over one shoulder, pay respect at the feet of the senior monks, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.3: “Venerables, I wish, by means of begging, to build a hut without a sponsoring owner and intended for myself.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.4: I request the Sangha to inspect the site for the hut.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.5: He should make his request a second
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.7: If the whole Sangha is able to inspect the site, they should all go.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.8: If the whole Sangha is not able to inspect the site, then those monks there who are competent and capable—who know where harm will be done and where no harm will be done, and who know what is meant by a space on all sides and a lack of space on all sides—should be asked and then appointed.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.9: “And, monks, they should be appointed like this.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.10: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.11: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.12: Monk so-and-so, by means of begging, wishes to build a hut without a sponsoring owner and intended for himself.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.13: He is requesting the Sangha to inspect the site for the hut.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.14: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should appoint monk so-and-so and monk so-and-so to inspect the site.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.16: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.17: Monk so-and-so, by means of begging, wishes to build a hut without a sponsoring owner and intended for himself.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.18: He is requesting the Sangha to inspect the site for the hut.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.19: The Sangha appoints monk so-and-so and monk so-and-so to inspect the site.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.20: Any monk who approves of appointing monk so-and-so and monk so-and-so to inspect the site for the hut should remain silent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.21: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.22: The Sangha has appointed monk so-and-so and monk so-and-so to inspect the site for a hut for monk so-and-so.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.23: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.25: The appointed monks should go and inspect the site for the hut to find out if any harm will be done and if it has a space on all sides.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.26: If harm will be done and it lacks a space on all sides, they should say, ‘Don’t build here.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.27: If no harm will be done and it has a space on all sides, they should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.28: ‘No harm will be done and it has a space on all sides.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.29: The monk who wishes to build the hut should then approach the Sangha, put his upper robe over one shoulder, pay respect at the feet of the senior monks, squat on his heels with his palms together, and say:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.30: ‘Venerables, I wish, by means of begging, to build a hut without a sponsoring owner and intended for myself.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.31: I request the Sangha to approve the site for the hut.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.32: He should make his request a second
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.34: A competent and capable monk should then inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.35: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.36: Monk so-and-so, by means of begging, wishes to build a hut without a sponsoring owner and intended for himself.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.37: He is requesting the Sangha to approve the site for the hut.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.38: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should approve the site.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.40: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.41: Monk so-and-so, by means of begging, wishes to build a hut without a sponsoring owner and intended for himself.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.42: He is requesting the Sangha to approve the site for the hut.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.43: The Sangha approves the site for the hut of monk so-and-so.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.44: Any monk who approves of approving the site for the hut should remain silent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.45: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.46: The Sangha has approved the site for a hut for monk so-and-so .
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.47: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.2: it is the abode of ants, termites, rats, snakes, scorpions, centipedes, elephants, horses, lions, tigers, leopards, bears, or hyenas, or any other animals;
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.3: or it is bordering on a field of grain, a field of vegetables, a slaughtering-place, a place of execution, a charnel ground, a park, a king’s property, an elephant-stable, a horse-stable, a prison, a bar, a slaughterhouse, a vehicle road, a crossroads, a public meeting hall, or a cul-de-sac—
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.4: this is called “where harm will be done”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.5: Which lacks a space on all sides:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.6: it is not possible to go around it with a yoked cart, or to go all the way around it with a ladder—this is called “which lacks a space on all sides”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.7: Where no harm will be done:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.8: it is not the abode of ants, termites, rats, snakes, scorpions, centipedes … it is not bordering on … a cul-de-sac—this is called “where no harm will be done”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.9: Which has a space on all sides:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.3.10: it is possible to go around it with a yoked cart, or to go all the way around it with a ladder—this is called “which has a space on all sides”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.4.2: having himself begged for a man, a servant … clay.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.4.4: plastered inside or plastered outside or plastered both inside and outside.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.4.6: building it himself or having someone else build it.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.4.7: Or he does not get monks to approve the site, or he exceeds the right size:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.4.8: if the site for the hut has not been approved through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements, or he builds a hut or has one built which exceeds the allowable length or breadth even by the width of a hair, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.4.9: When one piece is left to complete the hut, he commits a serious offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.4.10: When the last piece is finished, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.4.11: He commits an offense entailing suspension:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.4.12: … Therefore, too, it is called “an offense entailing suspension”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.1.1: If a monk builds a hut whose site has not been approved, where harm will be done, and which lacks a space on all sides, he commits one offense entailing suspension and two offenses of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.1.2: If a monk builds a hut whose site has not been approved, where harm will be done, but which has a space on all sides, he commits one offense entailing suspension and one offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.1.3: If a monk builds a hut whose site has not been approved, where no harm will be done, but which lacks a space on all sides, he commits one offense entailing suspension and one offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.1.4: If a monk builds a hut whose site has not been approved, where no harm will be done, and which has a space on all sides, he commits one offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.1.5: If a monk builds a hut whose site has been approved, where harm will be done, and which lacks a space on all sides, he commits two offenses of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.1.6: If a monk builds a hut whose site has been approved, where harm will be done, but which has a space on all sides, he commits one offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.1.7: If a monk builds a hut whose site has been approved, where no harm will be done, but which lacks a space on all sides, he commits one offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.1.8: If a monk builds a hut whose site has been approved, where no harm will be done, and which has a space on all sides, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.2.1: If a monk builds a hut which exceeds the right size, where harm will be done, and which lacks a space on all sides, he commits one offense entailing suspension and two offenses of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.2.2: If a monk builds a hut which exceeds the right size, where harm will be done, but which has a space on all sides, he commits one offense entailing suspension and one offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.2.3: If a monk builds a hut which exceeds the right size, where no harm will be done, but which lacks a space on all sides, he commits one offense entailing suspension and one offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.2.4: If a monk builds a hut which exceeds the right size, where no harm will be done, and which has a space on all sides, he commits one offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.2.5: If a monk builds a hut which is the right size, where harm will be done, and which lacks a space on all sides, he commits two offenses of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.2.6: If a monk builds a hut which is the right size, where harm will be done, but which has a space on all sides, he commits one offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.2.7: If a monk builds a hut which is the right size, where no harm will be done, but which lacks a space on all sides, he commits one offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.2.8: If a monk builds a hut which is the right size, where no harm will be done, and which has a space on all sides, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.3.1: If a monk builds a hut whose site has not been approved, which exceeds the right size, where harm will be done, and which lacks a space on all sides, he commits two offenses entailing suspension and two offenses of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.3.2: If a monk builds a hut whose site has not been approved, which exceeds the right size, where harm will be done, but which has a space on all sides, he commits two offenses entailing suspension and one offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.3.3: If a monk builds a hut whose site has not been approved, which exceeds the right size, where no harm will be done, but which lacks a space on all sides, he commits two offenses entailing suspension and one offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.3.4: If a monk builds a hut whose site has not been approved, which exceeds the right size, where no harm will be done, and which has a space on all sides, he commits two offenses entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.4.1: If a monk builds a hut whose site has been approved, which is the right size, where harm will be done, and which lacks a space on all sides, he commits two offenses of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.4.2: If a monk builds a hut whose site has been approved, which is the right size, where harm will be done, but which has a space on all sides, he commits one offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.4.3: If a monk builds a hut whose site has been approved, which is the right size, where no harm will be done, but which lacks a space on all sides, he commits one offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.4.4: If a monk builds a hut whose site has been approved, which is the right size, where no harm will be done, and which has a space on all sides, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.5.3: If they build a hut whose site has not been approved, where harm will be done, and which lacks a space on all sides, he commits one offense entailing suspension and two offenses of wrong conduct. …

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.14: If it is unfinished when he returns, that hut is to be given to someone else, or it is to be demolished and rebuilt.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.15: If he does not give it to someone else, or does not demolish and rebuild it, he commits two offenses of wrong conduct. …
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.16: where harm will be done, but which has a space on all sides, he commits one offense of wrong conduct. …
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.17: where no harm will be done, but which lacks a space on all sides, he commits one offense of wrong conduct. …
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.18: where no harm will be done, and which has a space on all sides, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.19: A monk appoints someone to build him a hut and then departs.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.20: They build one which exceeds the right size, where harm will be done, and which lacks a space on all sides.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.21: If it is unfinished when he returns, that hut is to be given to someone else, or it is to be demolished and rebuilt.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.22: If he does not give it to someone else, or does not demolish and rebuild it, he commits one offense entailing suspension and two offenses of wrong conduct. …
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.23: where harm will be done, but which has a space on all sides, he commits one offense entailing suspension and one offense of wrong conduct. …
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.24: where no harm will be done, but which lacks a space on all sides, he commits one offense entailing suspension and one offense of wrong conduct. …
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.25: where no harm will be done, and which has a space on all sides, he commits one offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.26: A monk appoints someone to build him a hut and then departs.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.27: They build one which is the right size, where harm will be done, and which lacks a space on all sides.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.28: If it is unfinished when he returns, that hut is to be given to someone else, or it is to be demolished and rebuilt.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.29: If he does not give it to someone else, or does not demolish and rebuild it, he commits two offenses of wrong conduct. …
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.30: where harm will be done, but which has a space on all sides, he commits one offense of wrong conduct. …
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.31: where no harm will be done, but which lacks a space on all sides, he commits one offense of wrong conduct. …
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.32: where no harm will be done, and which has a space on all sides, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.33: A monk appoints someone to build him a hut and then departs.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.34: They build a hut whose site has not been approved, which exceeds the right size, where harm will be done, and which lacks a space on all sides.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.35: If it is unfinished when he returns, that hut is to be given to someone else, or it is to be demolished and rebuilt.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.36: If he does not give it to someone else, or does not demolish and rebuild it, he commits two offenses entailing suspension and two offenses of wrong conduct. …
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.37: where harm will be done, but which has a space on all sides, he commits two offenses entailing suspension and one offense of wrong conduct. …
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.38: where no harm will be done, but which lacks a space on all sides, he commits two offenses entailing suspension and one offense of wrong conduct. …
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.39: where no harm will be done, and which has a space on all sides, he commits two offenses entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.40: A monk appoints someone to build him a hut and then departs.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.41: They build a hut whose site has been approved, which is the right size, where harm will be done, and which lacks a space on all sides.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.42: If it is unfinished when he returns, that hut is to be given to someone else, or it is to be demolished and rebuilt.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.43: If he does not give it to someone else, or does not demolish and rebuild it, he commits two offenses of wrong conduct. …
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.44: where harm will be done, but which has a space on all sides, he commits one offense of wrong conduct. …
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.45: where no harm will be done, but which lacks a space on all sides, he commits one offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.46: A monk appoints someone to build him a hut and then departs.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.14.47: They build a hut whose site has been approved, which is the right size, where no harm will be done, and which has a space on all sides, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.15.1: If he finishes what he began himself, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.15.2: If he gets others to finish what he began himself, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.15.3: If he finishes himself what was begun by others, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.15.4: If he gets others to finish what was begun by others, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.16.4: if it is a grass hut;
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.16.5: if it is built for someone else;
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.16.6: if it is anything apart from a dwelling;
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.16.8: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:3.16.9: The sixth rule, the training rule on building huts, is finished.
